STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM

STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM - APPROXIMATELY 50,000 BABIES IN THE STATE OF UTAH ARE SCREENED ANNUALLY FOR CONDITIONS THAT ARE NOT READILY APPARENT AT BIRTH BUT REQUIRE IMMEDIATE MEDICAL TREATMENT. THE ADDITION OF NEW DISORDERS TO THE RECOMMENDED UNIFORM SCREENING PANEL (RUSP) REQUIRES THE DEVELOPMENT AND VALIDATION OF THE LABORATORY ASSAY(S). IT ALSO REQUIRES THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE CORRESPONDING SUPPORTING WORKFLOWS, DISORDER LOGIC AND CASE MANAGEMENT WORKFLOWS IN THE LABORATORY INFORMATION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (LIMS).   POPULATION WIDE SCREENING AND HIGH COMPLIANCE THEREOF RELIES ON CHAIN OF CUSTODY (COC) SOLUTIONS THAT NOT ONLY ENSURES THAT ALL BABIES ARE SCREENED BUT ALSO PROVIDES EFFECTIVE AND MEANINGFUL INVENTION MECHANISMS WHEN A SCREEN IS NOT COLLECTED OR RECEIVED TIMELY. ELECTRONIC NOTIFICATIONS OF BIRTHING EVENTS THROUGH ADMIT, DISCHARGE, AND TRANSFER (ADT) MESSAGES TOGETHER WITH THE CORRESPONDING ELECTRONIC LABORATORY ORDERS (ELO) AND ELECTRONIC LABORATORY RESULTS (ELR) NOT ONLY LAY THE FOUNDATIONS FOR EFFECTIVE COC SOLUTIONS BUT ARE ALSO THE CENTRAL ELEMENTS LAY FOR LONG-TERM FOLLOW-UP (LTFU) MECHANISMS.  THIS PROPOSAL AIMS TO IMPLEMENT SCREENING FOR NEW DISORDERS (FOCUS AREA 1) AND COMPLETE WORK IN PROGRESS TOWARDS THE ESTABLISHMENT OF AN INTEROPERABILITY FRAMEWORK TO SUPPORT ELECTRONIC ORDERING AND RESULTS REPORTING WHICH ARE NECESSARY FOR COC AND LTFU MECHANISMS (FOCUS AREA 2). SPECIFICALLY, THE ACTIVITIES WE PROPOSE THAT ARE ASSOCIATED WITH THE EXPANSION OF THE UTAH NBS PANEL (FOCUS AREA 1) FOCUS ON ECONOMIES OF SCALE AND EXPANDING OUR SCALABLE, MULTIPLEX SCREENING PLATFORM BY MULTIPLE DISORDERS AT ONCE. THE FOCUS AREA INCLUDES THE CREATION OF AN EVALUATION SUBCOMMITTEE TO DEFINE DISORDER PRIORITIES TO DEVELOP A VETTED RECOMMENDED LIST OF DISORDERS TO POTENTIALLY ADD TO THE UTAH NBS PANEL, PRIMARY AND SECONDARY ASSAY DEVELOPMENT FOR THESE PRIORITIZED DISORDERS, VALIDATION OF THESE NEW METHODS, THE IMPLEMENTATION OF SUPPORTING LIMS REPORTING STRUCTURES, AND ULTIMAT ELY EXPANDED SCREENING IMPLEMENTATION.  THE WORK WE PROPOSE TO ESTABLISH AN INTEROPERABILITY FRAMEWORK TO SUPPORT COC AND LTFU (FOCUS AREA 2) INCLUDES THE COMPLETION OF DEVELOPMENT ON ELO/ELR FRAMEWORK WITH THREE LARGE HEALTHCARE SYSTEMS IN UTAH (IHC, STEWARD, U OF U), IMPLEMENTATION OF ELO/ELR, THE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF A NBS WEB PORTAL, AND EXPLORATION OF ADT MESSAGE INTEGRATION. THE WEB PORTAL WOULD SERVE SMALLER BIRTHING CENTERS, CLINICS, AND MIDWIVES WHO EITHER LACK ACCESS TO AN EHR OR ARE NOT ABLE TO SUPPORT ELO/ELR IMPLEMENTATION. THE PORTAL WOULD SUPPORT NBS KIT REGISTRATION, RESULTS REPORTING AND SERVE AS A LOOK-UP TOOL FOR LTFU PURPOSES. IN ADDITION TO THE WEB PORTAL, THE ADT MESSAGE CAN ALSO BE USED FOR THE PURPOSES OF LTFU AND COC. OUR PROGRAM WOULD LIKE TO EXPLORE WAYS TO ACCESS THIS MESSAGE AND IMPLEMENT FILTERS THAT WOULD ALERT WHEN A PATIENT PRESENTS WITH SYMPTOMS CONSISTENT WITH A NBS DISORDER AND TRIGGER LTFU WORKFLOW.   THE PROPOSED WORK DESCRIBED IN THIS GRANT WILL BENEFIT ALL NEWBORNS AND THEIR FAMILIES IN UTAH AS WELL AS BABIES BORN IN UTAH FROM SURROUNDING STATES. THE AWARDED FUNDS WILL PROVIDE THE CAPABILITY OF THE UTAH NBS PROGRAM TO ESTABLISH A SYSTEMATIC PROCESS FOR IDENTIFYING ADDITIONAL  DISORDERS THAT CAN BE INCLUDED OR MULTIPLEXED IN OUR DEVELOPED MULTIPLEX SCREENING PLATFORM AND IMPLEMENT THE EXPANDED SCREENING ASSAY AND LIMS INFRASTRUCTURE TO SUPPORT SUCH EXPANDED SCREENING. IN PARALLEL, WE WILL DEVELOP STANDARDS-BASED ELECTRONIC MESSAGING TO SUPPORT COC AND LTFU ALSO NECESSARY FOR SOME OF THESE DISORDERS.

STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM - PROJECT ABSTRACT DESCRIPTIVE TITLE: TAKING NEWBORN SCREENING TO THE NEXT LEVEL THROUGH EXPANDED TESTING AND IMPROVED SPECIMEN TRANSIT TIME ADDRESS: 465 HENRY MALL, MADISON, WISCONSIN 53706 PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME: ROBERTO MENDEZ, PHD CONTACT PHONE NUMBERS: (608) 265-5968 EMAIL ADDRESS: ROBERTO.MENDEZ@SLH.WISC.EDU GRANT PROGRAM FUNDS REQUESTED: HRSA-23-065 (FOCUS AREA 1) THE WISCONSIN NEWBORN SCREENING LABORATORY PERFORMS VALUABLE TESTING FOR THE RESIDENTS OF WISCONSIN. A NUMBER OF FACTORS AFFECT OUR ABILITY TO CARRY OUT THIS DUTY EFFECTIVELY, INCLUDING THE NUMBER OF DISEASES WE ARE CAPABLE OF SCREENING AND THE TIMELINESS OF OUR REPORTED RESULTS.  CURRENTLY, THERE ARE THREE DISORDERS ON THE RUSP FOR WHICH OUR LABORATORY HAS NOT DEVELOPED SPECIFIC SCREENING METHODS.  THESE DISORDERS ARE MUCOPOLYSACCHARIDOSIS TYPES I AND II (MPS I AND MPS II) AND GUANIDINOACETATE METHYLTRANSFERASE DEFICIENCY (GAMT). WE AIM TO DEVELOP TESTS IN PREPARATION FOR THE TIME THAT THESE DISORDERS ARE ADDED TO THE WISCONSIN NEWBORN SCREENING PANEL. THE SCREENING METHODS WILL BE COMPOSED OF ALTERATIONS OF CURRENTLY USED METHODS, AS WELL AS NEW LABORATORY DEVELOPED TESTS. BY DEVELOPING THESE ASSAYS, WE WILL FACILITATE THE ADDITION OF THE ABOVE-MENTIONED DISORDERS TO THE WISCONSIN NEWBORN SCREENING PANEL AND IMPROVE LABORATORY READINESS AHEAD OF THEIR ADDITION. ALSO, INCLUDING THE PROPOSED METHODS IN OUR PROTOCOLS WILL ALSO LEAVE US BETTER PREPARED FOR SCREENING OF OTHER RELATED DISORDERS THAT COULD POTENTIALLY BE ADDED TO THE RUSP IN THE FUTURE. IN ADDITION TO THE ABILITY TO SCREEN FOR A DISORDER, THE ABILITY TO REPORT RESULTS TO CLINICIANS EARLY IN THE LIFE OF AN INFANT IS CRITICAL TO OUR ROLE IN PUBLIC HEALTH. TRANSIT TIME, THE DAYS BETWEEN SPECIMEN COLLECTION AND RECEIPT AT THE TESTING LABORATORY, IS A KEY PHASE OF THE PRE-ANALYTICAL NBS PROCESS THAT IMPACTS THE OVERALL TIMELINESS OF IDENTIFYING AT-RISK NEWBORNS. WE PLAN TO DEVELOP WORKFLOWS AND ENHANCE EXISTING TRANSIT TIME REPORTS TO PROVIDE DETAILED CATEGORIZATION OF THE CAUSE(S) OF EACH TRANSIT TIME DELAY. WE WILL USE THIS DATA TO ASSESS THE PERFORMANCE OF STAKEHOLDERS AT EACH STAGE IN THE TRANSIT PROCESS, AND TO IDENTIFY SPECIFIC TARGETS FOR QUALITY IMPROVEMENT EFFORTS. WE AIM TO IMPROVE THE TIMELINESS OF SPECIMEN TRANSIT BY FOCUSING SUBMITTER ENGAGEMENT ON WAYS TO SHORTEN THE TIME BETWEEN COLLECTION AND SHIPMENT OF NBS SPECIMENS. IF SUCCESSFUL, WE WILL BE ABLE TO MOVE THE WISCONSIN TRANSIT TIME QUALITY INDICATOR BENCHMARK FROM SPECIMENS RECEIVED WITHIN 3 DAYS OF COLLECTION TO SPECIMEN RECEIVED WITHIN 2 DAYS OF COLLECTION. BY EXPANDING THE TESTING PANEL AND REDUCING TRANSIT TIME, WE WILL IMPROVE OUTCOMES FOR NEWBORN INFANTS WITH INHERITED DISORDERS. THERE ARE TWO SPECIFIC AIMS IN THIS PROPOSAL: SPECIFIC AIM 1: EXPAND TESTING CAPABILITY TO IMPROVE LABORATORY READINESS FOR SCREENING MUCOPOLYSACCHARIDOSIS TYPES I AND II (MPS I AND MPS II), AND GUANIDINOACETATE METHYLTRANSFERASE (GAMT) DEFICIENCY. SPECIFIC AIM 2: IMPROVE NBS SPECIMEN TRANSIT TIME VIA INCREASING TRANSPARENCY AND EFFECTIVE COMMUNICATION.

STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM - HRSA-23-065 STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM (NBS PROPEL) PD: DR. SULAY RIVERA-SÁNCHEZ PR CENTER FOR INHERITED DISEASES PR NEWBORN SCREENING PROGRAM UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MEDICAL SCIENCES CAMPUS PO BOX 365067  SAN JUAN PR 00936-5067 E: SULAY.RIVERA@UPR.EDU TEL: 787-754-7410, 787-753-6340 FAX: 787-767-8597 WEBSITE:  HTTPS://PCNPR.RCM.UPR.EDU/  THE PUERTO RICO NEWBORN SCREENING (PR NBS) PROGRAM CONDUCTED THROUGH THE UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO-MEDICAL SCIENCES CAMPUS, HAS BEEN SUCCESSFULLY WORKING TO DETECT TREATABLE HEREDITARY CONDITIONS IN NEWBORNS AVERTING SERIOUS AND POTENTIALLY LIFE-THREATENING COMPLICATIONS.  THE NBS PROGRAM HAS BEEN PROVIDING UNINTERRUPTED SERVICE FOR MORE THAN 30 YEARS, HOWEVER, DIFFERENT BARRIERS RELATED TO TIMELINESS AND THE FOLLOW-UP SYSTEM STILL NEED TO BE ADDRESSED TO CONTINUE IMPROVING THE NBS SERVICE. SOME OF THESE BARRIERS INCLUDE:  A MANUAL REPORT OF RESULTS, SAMPLES BATCHING IN HOSPITALS TO MANAGE TRANSPORT EXPENSES, STAFF SHORTAGE AND HIGH TURNOVER RATE OF EMPLOYEES, LACK OF SPECIALISTS, AND LIMITED CONFIRMATORY AND FOLLOW-UP TESTING.  IN THIS PROJECT, WE PROPOSE TO IMPROVE TIMELY COLLECTION AND REPORTING OF NBS SPECIMENS.  ALSO, WE EXPECT TO IMPROVE THE SHORT-TERM FOLLOW-UP SYSTEM TO COMPLETE THE CONFIRMATORY TESTING AND HAVE AN ADEQUATE AND PROMPT MEDICAL EVALUATION OF PATIENTS.  MOREOVER, WE PROPOSE TO IMPLEMENT AND PROVIDE LABORATORY SERVICES TO THE PHENYLKETONURIA PATIENTS IN PR FOR AN ADEQUATE LONG-TERM FOLLOW-UP AND MANAGEMENT.   DIFFERENT STRATEGIES WILL BE USED TO ACHIEVE THE GOALS PROPOSED IN THIS PROJECT INCLUDING EDUCATIONAL APPROACHES, THE ESTABLISHMENT OF AN EFFICIENT COURIER SYSTEM, OPTIMIZATION OF HEALTH INFORMATION TECHNOLOGIES, EXPANSION OF LABORATORY SERVICES AND RECRUITMENT OF STAFF. THESE INTERVENTIONS ARE EXPECTED TO IMPROVE THE NBS SYSTEM AND TO PROVIDE EQUITABLE ACCESS TO HEALTH CARE SERVICES FOR INFANTS AND FAMILIES.

STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM - PROJECT TITLE: EXPANSION OF NEWBORN SCREENING USING NEW TECHNOLOGIES APPLICANT NAME: NEW ENGLAND NEWBORN SCREENING PROGRAM, UMASS CHAN MEDICAL SCHOOL APPLICANT ADDRESS: 377 PLANTATION STREET, BIOTECH 4, WORCESTER, MA 01605 PROJECT DIRECTOR: ANNE MARIE COMEAU, PH.D. PHONE NUMBER: 774-455-4600 FAX: 774-455-4657  EMAIL ADDRESS: ANNE.COMEAU@UMASSMED.EDU WEBSITE: HTTPS://NENSP.UMASSMED.EDU  AMOUNT REQUESTED: $345,000/YEAR FOR 5 YEARS  BACKGROUND: THE NEW ENGLAND NEWBORN SCREENING PROGRAM OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS CHAN MEDICAL SCHOOL (NENSP UMASS CHAN) PROVIDES COMPREHENSIVE NEWBORN SCREENING SERVICES FOR ALL MASSACHUSETTS NEWBORNS. ADDITIONALLY, WE PROVIDE NEWBORN SCREENING LABORATORY SERVICES AND CONSULTATION TO THE STATES OF MAINE, NEW HAMPSHIRE, RHODE ISLAND, AND VERMONT.   PROPOSED SERVICES: THE OVER-ARCHING GOAL IS TO MAKE AVAILABLE AN ONGOING SERIES OF VALIDATED NEWBORN SCREENING PROGRAM ASSAYS AND ALGORITHMS FOR EARLY IDENTIFICATION OF INFANTS WITH CONDITIONS RECOMMENDED BY THE SECRETARY’S ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON HERITABLE DISORDERS IN NEWBORNS AND CHILDREN (SACHDNC) FOR INCLUSION IN THE RECOMMENDED UNIFORM SCREENING PANEL (RUSP).   NEEDS TO BE ADDRESSED: THE SPECIFIC NEEDS TO BE ADDRESSED INCLUDE: DEVELOPING THE TECHNOLOGICAL CAPACITY TO OFFER SCREENING SERVICES FOR NEW CONDITIONS ON AND TO BE ON THE RUSP; EXPANDING ACCESS TO QUALITY DIAGNOSTIC EVALUATION, SELECTING WHICH INFANTS NEED REFERRAL MORE ACCURATELY AND PROVIDING JUST-IN-TIME DATA FOR THE REFERRAL; ENSURING THAT THE ASSAYS USED IN NEWBORN SCREENING ADEQUATELY ADDRESS THE DIVERSITY OF OUR POPULATION; ENSURING THAT INFANTS WHO ARE SEEN AT FEDERALLY QUALIFIED HEALTH CENTERS (FQHCS) HAVE TIMELY REFERRALS AND THE MEANS TO ACCESS THESE REFERRALS;  DEVELOPING MORE DETAILED TIMELINESS DATA SO THAT IT CAN BE USED FOR QUALITY IMPROVEMENTS.   POPULATION GROUP TO BE SERVED: THE PRIMARY TARGET POPULATION FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDES ALL THE ~70,000 NEWBORNS BORN IN MASSACHUSETTS EACH YEAR AN D THEIR FAMILIES. THERE WILL BE A PARTICULAR EMPHASIS ON THOSE REQUIRING FOLLOW-UP (THOSE PROMPTING SECOND TIER TESTING AND/OR HAVING A POSITIVE NBS REQUIRING REFERRAL FOR DIAGNOSTIC TESTING) AND THOSE FOLLOWED AT FQHCS.   PROPOSED PROJECT AND METHODOLOGY: OUR PRIMARY METHODOLOGICAL APPROACH WILL BE LABORATORY-BASED. WE WILL DEVELOP, OPTIMIZE, AND VALIDATE SCREENING ASSAYS FOR NEW CONDITIONS. THESE ASSAYS WILL ENCOMPASS THE PRIMARY SCREENING TEST AS WELL AS OTHER SUPPLEMENTAL TESTS THAT MIGHT BE NEEDED TO EITHER HELP 1) MORE ACCURATELY SELECT WHICH NEONATES NEED ADDITIONAL TESTING OR 2) CLARIFY A DIAGNOSIS. WE WILL ALSO SEEK TO ENHANCE EXISTING COMMUNICATIONS BETWEEN OUR PROGRAM AND SPECIALTY PROVIDERS AND PROGRAMS AND DIVISIONS AT THE MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH BY UTILIZING FEEDBACK LOOPS. WE WILL WORK TO DISCOVER INNOVATIVE SOLUTIONS FOR GAINING TIMELY ATTENTION OF PROVIDERS SERVING UNDERPRIVILEGED COMMUNITIES, SUCH AS THOSE SEEN AND FOLLOWED AT FQHCS, TO ENSURE EXPEDIENT REFERRALS TO DIAGNOSTIC EVALUATIONS. THE COMBINED METHODS WILL FACILITATE EXPANDED ACCESS TO EQUITABLE QUALITY DIAGNOSTIC EVALUATION, UTILIZING RESULTS GENERATED BY THE NEWBORN SCREENING PROGRAM.  OUTCOMES: WE WILL PROVIDE THE EVIDENCE BASE FOR QUALITY IMPROVEMENTS IN LABORATORY SCREENING, NOTIFICATION, DIAGNOSTIC, AND TREATMENT PRACTICES. WE WILL MAKE AVAILABLE A SUSTAINABLE APPROACH TO IMPLEMENTATION OF SCREENING NEWBORNS FOR NEW CONDITIONS WITH DEMONSTRATED UTILITY THROUGH PROSPECTIVE IMPLEMENTATION OF STATEWIDE SCREENING. WE WILL MAKE THE ALGORITHMS’ ASSAYS AND STRATEGIES READILY AVAILABLE TO OTHER PUBLIC HEALTH NEWBORN SCREENING LABORATORIES FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF UNIVERSAL NEWBORN SCREENING FOR THESE CONDITIONS. WE WILL BUILD UPON THE COMBINED EXPERTISE OF LABORATORY SCIENCE AND COMMUNITY RELATIONSHIPS, TO DEVELOP NEW STRATEGIES TO ENSURE CONTINUED AND BETTER COMMUNICATIONS WITH A SPECTRUM OF MASSACHUSETTS FAMILIES, PARTICULARLY THOSE IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES.

STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM - NORTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES 2025 MAIL SERVICE CENTER RALEIGH, NC 27699-2000  SCOTT M. SHONE, PHD, HCLD(ABB) 919-807-8990 (PHONE) 919-733-8695 (FAX) SCOTT.SHONE@DHHS.NC.GOV  HRSA-23-065 STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM (NBS PROPEL) TOTAL FUNDS REQUESTED: $1,723,126 PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE: 7/1/23 TO 6/30/28  NEWBORN SCREENING (NBS) IS A LONG-STANDING PUBLIC HEALTH PROGRAM TO IDENTIFY DISORDERS IN NEWBORNS THAT NEED IMMEDIATE INTERVENTION TO PREVENT MEDICAL COMPLICATIONS, INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY, OR EVEN DEATH. NATIONALLY, NBS PROGRAMS FACE SEVERAL CURRENT AND FUTURE CHALLENGES. RECENT WORK HAS HIGHLIGHTED THE NEED FOR NBS PROGRAMS TO PREPARE FOR THE FUTURE IN WHICH SIGNIFICANTLY MORE CONDITIONS MAY BE NOMINATED FOR THE FEDERAL RECOMMEND UNIFORM SCREENING PANEL (RUSP) AND NEW SCREENING TECHNOLOGIES ARE AVAILABLE. THE PROPOSED PROJECT, ADVANCING NORTH CAROLINA NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES, IS IN RESPONSE TO HRSA-23-065, STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM (NBS PROPEL). THE GOALS OF THE NC NBS PROPEL PROJECT ARE TO IMPROVE IT DATA SYSTEMS AND DATA COLLECTION THROUGH IMPROVEMENTS TO THE NC INFORMATION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM, STRENGTHENING LINKAGES BETWEEN LABORATORY AND FOLLOW-UP DATA SYSTEMS, AND CREATING AN INFRASTRUCTURE FOR THE COLLECTION AND REPORTING OF TIMELINESS INDICTORS AND LONG-TERM FOLLOW-UP DATA; ENHANCING LABORATORY AND FOLLOW-UP PROCEDURES BY REFINING A COOP, REVIEWING AND UPDATING SCREENING ALGORITHMS AND CUT-OFFS, CONDUCTING QUALITY IMPROVEMENT (QI) PROJECTS, AND IMPLEMENTING SCREENING FOR NEW DISORDERS; AND EXPAND FOLLOW-UP AND EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES WITH PROVIDERS, INCLUDING CLINICIANS AND BIRTHING FACILITIES, AND FAMILIES TO IMPROVE HEALTH EQUITY. TO ACHIEVE THESE GOALS, THE NC NBS TEAM WILL WORK WITH PARTNERS AT RTI INTERNATIONAL. THE NC NBS PROGRAM AND RTI HAVE A STRONG TRACK RECORD OF COLLABORATION IN NBS RESEARCH, PILOT STUDIES, AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE, WHICH HAS STREN GTHENED THE NC NBS SYSTEM. AT THE CONCLUSION OF THE PROJECT, THE NC NBS PROGRAM WILL SEE AN INCREASE IN THE NUMBER OF NBS SPECIMENS COLLECTED WITHIN 48 HOURS OF BIRTH, THE NUMBER OF PRESUMPTIVE POSITIVE RESULTS FOR TIME-CRITICAL CONDITIONS THAT ARE COMMUNICATED IMMEDIATELY TO THE NEWBORN’S HEALTHCARE PROVIDER BUT NO LATER THAN 5 DAYS AFTER BIRTH, AND THE NUMBER OF ALL NBS RESULTS (NORMAL AND OUT-OF-RANGE) THAT ARE REPORTED WITHIN 7 DAYS OF BIRTH, OVERALL AND FOR ALL RACES AND ETHNICITIES.

STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM - THE HRSA FUNDING OPPORTUNITY “STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM” (NBS PROPEL, HRSA-23-065) WILL ASSIST THE GEORGIA NBS PROGRAM IN IMPLEMENTATION OF A ROBUST, RAPID, AND ACCURATE TEST TO IDENTIFY INFANTS AT RISK OF SCID AND IMPROVE TIME TO DIAGNOSIS. SCID IS A GROUP OF IMMUNE DEFICIENCY DISORDERS PREVENTING CHILDREN FROM DEVELOPING A FUNCTIONING T CELL LYMPHOCYTE IMMUNE SYSTEM. WITHOUT EFFECTIVE TREATMENT, CHILDREN SUCCUMB TO SEVERE OPPORTUNISTIC INFECTIONS. RECOGNITION OF SCID IN THE NEWBORN PERIOD IS DIFFICULT, AS THERE ARE OFTEN NO SIGNS OR SYMPTOMS EXCEPT THE EVENTUAL DEVELOPMENT OF A SEVERE INFECTION. THE GEORGIA PUBLIC HEALTH LABORATORY PERFORMS NEWBORN SCREENING (NBS) FOR SCID ON ALL INFANTS IN GEORGIA, HOWEVER, THE TIME BETWEEN IDENTIFYING A POSITIVE SCREEN, CONFIRMATORY TESTING, AND TREATMENT CAN VARY GREATLY AND IMPACT THE HEALTH OF THE INFANT. THERE ARE MULTIPLE POINTS FOR IMPROVEMENT IN TIME TO IDENTIFYING AND TREATING AFFECTED INFANTS. THIS PROPOSAL WILL ADDRESS BOTH LABORATORY IMPROVEMENTS AS WELL AS CLINICAL REFERRAL, DIAGNOSIS AND MONITORING.  TURNAROUND TIME FROM RECEIPT OF THE NBS ORDER UNTIL REPORTING THE RESULTS TO HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS IS IMPACTED BY THE TESTING USED AND THE DATA HANDLING PROCESSES FROM ORDER RECEIPT TO REPORTING.  LABORATORY EFFORTS WILL INCLUDE IMPLEMENTATION AND EVALUATION OF A NEW FDA APPROVED SCID SCREENING METHOD TO DECREASE FALSE POSITIVE RESULTS, WITH FEWER REPEATED SPECIMENS AND GREATER ACCURACY IN IDENTIFICATION OF AT RISK BABIES. THE LABORATORY WILL ALSO IMPLEMENT ELECTRONIC ORDERING AND REPORTING TO IMPROVE DEMOGRAPHIC ACCURACY AND RAPID DELIVERY OF REPORT DATA BACK TO PROVIDERS. MANY ABNORMAL SCID RESULTS CAN BE RESOLVED WITH A REPEAT NBS SAMPLE, BUT HIGHER RISK RESULTS SHOWING NO T CELLS REQUIRE CLINICAL CONFIRMATORY TESTING INCLUDING LYMPHOCYTE ENUMERATION BY FLOW CYTOMETRY.  OFTEN THESE CHILDREN DO NOT RECEIVE THE CORRECT TYPE OF FLOW CYTOMETRY FOR SCID FOLLOW UP.  THIS REQUIRE S HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS TO RECONTACT FAMILIES, WRITE NEW ORDERS, AND CHILDREN MUST RETURN FOR A NEW BLOOD DRAW.  THESE ERRORS RESULT IN DELAYS IN OBTAINING A FINAL DISPOSITION FOR THE CHILD AND FINANCIAL BURDENS ACROSS THE HEALTHCARE SYSTEM, ESPECIALLY FOR FAMILIES. IMPORTANTLY, THESE DELAYS CREATE AN EMOTIONAL BURDEN FOR FAMILIES AS THEY WAIT TO KNOW IF THEIR CHILD IS CRITICALLY ILL. DATA ON CLINICAL DIAGNOSTIC TEST COLLECTION TYPES AND ASSOCIATED TIME POINTS WILL HELP THE GEORGIA FOLLOW UP PROGRAM TO UNDERSTAND THE SCOPE OF THIS PROBLEM, IDENTIFY GEOGRAPHIC AREAS THAT MAY EXPERIENCE MORE DELAYS OR PROBLEMS THAN OTHERS, AND PROVIDE DATA TO SUPPORT INTERVENTIONS.  DR. BONITA TAFFE, PI, BONITA.TAFFE@DPH.GA.GOV GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH 1743 CLAIRMONT ROAD, DECATUR, GA 404-327-7905 (PH), 404-327-7919 (FAX)

STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM - THE TEXAS DEPARTMENT OF STATE HEALTH SERVICES (DSHS) ADMINISTERS THE LARGEST NEWBORN SCREENING (NBS) PROGRAM IN THE UNITED STATES, PROCESSING APPROXIMATELY 750,000 BLOODSPOT SPECIMENS FOR 55 HERITABLE OR CONGENITAL CONDITIONS ANNUALLY. THIS PROPOSAL REQUESTS FUNDING TO ADDRESS TIMELINESS AND EQUITABLE ACCESS TO CARE BY IMPROVING TWO COMPONENTS THE NBS PROGRAM: 1) THE DEMOGRAPHIC DATA ENTRY PROCESS WITHIN LABORATORY SECTION SERVICES, WHERE THE DEMOGRAPHIC DATA FORMS ARE RECEIVED AND DATA ENTERED, AND 2) THE NEWBORN SCREENING UNIT WITHIN TEXAS MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH, WHICH OVERSEES CLINICAL FOLLOW-UP OF HERITABLE CONDITIONS IDENTIFIED THROUGH BLOODSPOT TESTING, AS WELL AS FOLLOW-UP OF SCREENINGS FOR NEWBORN HEARING AND CRITICAL CONGENITAL HEART CONDITIONS.   THE FIRST PROJECT (ADDRESSING FOCUS AREA 1) PROPOSES TO INTRODUCE OPTICAL CHARACTER RECOGNITION (OCR) IN THE DEMOGRAPHIC DATA ENTRY PROCESS WITH THE GOAL OF SAME-DAY DATA ENTRY FOR 100% OF SPECIMENS RECEIVED. SAME-DAY DATA ENTRY WOULD ALLOW FOR GREATER SPECIFICITY OF INITIAL PHASE TESTING AND DIRECTLY IMPACT THE TIMELINESS OF PRESUMPTIVE POSITIVE DETERMINATIONS FOR TIME-CRITICAL TESTING, AS THE CURRENT RATE OF SAME-DAY DATA ENTRY IS LOW DUE TO THE LABOR-INTENSIVE PROCESS. AUTOMATING A PORTION OF THIS PROCESS WILL GREATLY REDUCE WORKLOAD ON DATA ENTRY STAFF AND MITIGATE A CAUSE OF HIGH TURNOVER.   THE INTEGRATION OF OCR INTO THE DATA ENTRY PROCESS WILL BE COMPLEMENTED BY AN EDUCATIONAL OUTREACH PROGRAM RELATED TO THE NEW SYSTEM, IN WHICH HOSPITALS, BIRTHING CENTERS, AND ANY NEWBORN SCREENING PROVIDERS ARE TAUGHT BEST PRACTICES FOR COMPLETING DEMOGRAPHIC SHEETS FOR MAXIMIZING OCR ACCURACY. THE EDUCATIONAL PROGRAM WILL ALSO ADDRESS GENERAL TIMELINESS ISSUES RELATED TO MISSING DEMOGRAPHIC INFORMATION AND SHIPMENT OF BLOODSPOT SPECIMENS TO DSHS. THIS PROJECT WILL BE OVERSEEN BY A DEDICATED PROJECT MANAGER.  THE SECOND PROJECT (ADDRESSING FOCUS AREA 2) TARGETS OPERATIONAL ISSUES WITHIN THE NEWBOR N SCREENING UNIT, WHICH, BECAUSE OF THE HIGH VOLUME OF NEWBORNS FLAGGED FOR FOLLOW-UP CARE IN TEXAS, IS SPLIT INTO THREE DISTINCT AREAS FOR FOLLOW-UP OF BLOODSPOT, HEARING, AND CRITICAL CONGENITAL HEART DISEASE CONDITIONS. THIS PROPOSAL REQUESTS FUNDS FOR A DEDICATED PROJECT MANAGER TO WORK ACROSS ALL THREE GROUPS; A UNIQUE VANTAGE POINT THAT WILL ALLOW FOR THE IDENTIFICATION OF GAPS AS WELL AS BEST PRACTICES WITHIN, AND AMONG, PROGRAM AREAS.  IN ADDITION, FUNDING FOR LABORATORY INFORMATION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (LIMS) MODIFICATIONS IS REQUESTED TO RESOLVE IDENTIFIED ISSUES.

STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM - SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROL 2600 BULL STREET, COLUMBIA, SC 29201 PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME: ELIZABETH BAIR PHONE: (803) 896-0991 EMAIL: BAIREA@DHEC.SC.GOV WEBSITE ADDRESS: HTTPS://SCDHEC.GOV/ GRANT PROGRAM FUNDS REQUESTED: $345,000/YEAR FOR YEARS 1-5  PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY THE SOUTH CAROLINA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROL (SC DHEC) PUBLIC HEALTH LABORATORY (PHL) AND THE SC DHEC BUREAU OF MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH (MCH BUREAU) AIM TO RAPIDLY SCALE-UP SOUTH CAROLINA’S NEWBORN SCREENING (NBS) CAPABILITIES AND OUTREACH EFFORTS TO ALIGN WITH NATIONAL NBS QUALITY IMPROVEMENT EFFORTS. SPECIFICALLY, SC DHEC AIMS TO ENHANCE NBS TIMELINESS, REDUCE MANUAL DATA ENTRY ERRORS, EXPAND THEIR RUSP TESTING MENU AND INCREASE HEALTH EQUITY AMONG SC RESIDENTS BY INTEGRATING A NEWBORN SCREENING DATA MANAGEMENT SUITE (NBS DMS) INTO THE STATE’S LABORATORY INFORMATION SYSTEM (LIMS). THE DMS WILL BE A CLOUD-BASED INFORMATION MANAGEMENT SYSTEM THAT WILL ENHANCE NEWBORN PATIENT CARE AND INTERVENTION TIMELINESS THROUGH SMART DATA INTEGRATION AND SECURE DATA SHARING AMONGST STAKEHOLDERS. THE PHL AND MCH BUREAU PLAN TO LEVERAGE LONGSTANDING PARTNERSHIPS WITH THE DIVISION OF VITAL STATISTICS AND SEVERAL CLINICAL INSTITUTIONS TO COLLABORATIVELY ACHIEVE PROGRAMMATIC SUCCESS. THE PHL WILL WORK CLOSELY WITH CLINICAL PARTNERS TO EQUIP FRONT LINE CLINICAL AND PUBLIC HEALTH STAFF WITH THE UNDERSTANDING OF NEWLY DEVELOPED NBS DATA MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS FOR USE IN THE RAPID SCREENING OF NEWBORNS. SIMILARLY, THE PHL AND MCH HAVE COOPERATIVE PLANS TO EXPAND SC DHEC’S COMMUNITY OUTREACH EFFORTS TO IMPROVE HEALTH EQUITY IN SOUTH CAROLINA (CREATION OF A NBS ONLINE COMMUNITY DASHBOARD, NBS MEDIA CAMPAIGNS, PHL STUDENT TOURS, ETC.). TO MANAGE STAKEHOLDER COLLABORATIONS, COORDINATE MODERNIZATION OF NBS DATA SYSTEMS AND FULFILL OTHER GRANT DELIVERABLES, SC DHEC WILL HIRE A PHL NBS PROPEL GRANT COORDINATOR. SC DHEC WILL ALSO RETAIN A PHL GRANT EVALUA TOR TO ROUTINELY EXECUTE SC DHEC’S NBS GRANT EVALUATION AND MONITORING SYSTEMS WITH THE HIGHEST LEVEL OF FIDELITY. THIS NBS PROPEL PROGRAM WILL SERVE THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA WELL AS SC DHEC 1) INNOVATES ITS NBS DATA MANAGEMENT SYSTEM AND TECHNICAL CAPACITY, 2) EXPANDS RUSP TESTING, AND 3) IMPROVES STATEWIDE NBS AWARENESS THROUGH ENHANCED NBS OUTREACH EFFORTS. COLLECTIVELY, THESE EFFORTS WILL HELP DHEC CONTINUE PROMOTING COMMUNITY HEALTH AND WELL-BEING FOR SC’S YOUNGEST RESIDENTS AND THEIR FAMILIES.

STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM - THIS PROPOSAL, WHICH WE ARE CALLING THE LAUNCH (LEVERAGING ACCESS TO A UNIFORM NEWBORN SCREENING CONTINUUM OF HEALTH) PROJECT, ADDRESSES THE PRIORITIZED NEEDS OF THE INSP.  THE GOALS OF THE LAUNCH PROJECT ARE FOURFOLD: 1.	TO IMPROVE THE INSP TIMELINESS OF NEWBORN SCREENING FROM BIRTH TO RESULTS REPORTING, WE WILL DEVELOP QUALITY IMPROVEMENT PLANS WITH BIRTHING FACILITIES THAT ARE UNDERPERFORMING WITH REGARD TO COLLECTION OF BLOOD SPOT SPECIMENS WITHIN 24 - 48 HOURS FROM BIRTH, SUBMISSION OF POOR QUALITY SPECIMENS, OR SUBMITTING SPECIMENS WITH INCOMPLETE OR INCORRECT INFORMATION 2.	TO EXPAND THE STATE HYGIENIC LABORATORY’S (SHL) CAPACITY TO DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT TESTS FOR NEW CONDITIONS, THE LAUNCH PROJECT WILL BUILD A PROCESS FOR PRIORITIZATION OF NEWBORN SCREENING CONDITIONS AND SECOND TIER TESTING. THIS PROCESS WILL ALSO EMPLOY A NEW CLINICAL LAB ANALYST POSITION TO SUPPORT THE EFFICIENT DEVELOPMENT AND DEPLOYMENT OF NEW TESTING METHODOLOGY. 3.	THE LAUNCH PROJECT WILL CULTIVATE A COMPREHENSIVE SYSTEM FOR LONG-TERM FOLLOW-UP (LTFU) OF NEWBORNS IDENTIFIED WITH A CONDITION DISCOVERED THROUGH INSP. THIS SYSTEM WILL ALLOW FOR THE ASSURANCE AND PROVISION OF QUALITY CHRONIC DISEASE MANAGEMENT, CONDITION-SPECIFIC TREATMENT, AND AGE-APPROPRIATE PREVENTATIVE CARE FOR INDIVIDUALS THROUGH AGE 18 IDENTIFIED WITH A CONDITION INCLUDED ON IOWA’S NEWBORN SCREENING PANEL. THIS PROJECT ALSO SEEKS TO BUILD A LONG-TERM SURVEILLANCE PROCESS TO ASSESS THE HEALTH STATUS AND HEALTH OUTCOMES OF THESE NEWBORNS IN ORDER TO ASSESS THE IMPACT ON THE INDIVIDUAL OF EARLY DETECTION AND INTERVENTION THAT IS AFFORDED TO THE INDIVIDUAL THROUGH THE INSP.  4.	THE LAUNCH PROJECT SEEKS TO IMPROVE ENGAGEMENT OF PARENTS, FAMILIES AND INDIVIDUALS AFFECTED BY A NEWBORN SCREENING CONDITION IN INSP PROGRAMMING.
STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM

STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM - THE STATE OF NEW HAMPSHIRE NEWBORN SCREENING PROGRAM (NBSP) IS LOCATED IN THE MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH SECTION OF THE NEW HAMPSHIRE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES. THE NBSP RECOGNIZES THE IMPORTANCE OF STRENGTHENING THE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM TO PROVIDE ALL INFANTS THE OPPORTUNITY TO BE SCREENED FOR HERITABLE DISORDERS, FOLLOW UP, AND PROVIDE COUNSELING AND HEALTH CARE SERVICES FOR CHILDREN, WITH OR AT RISK, TO HELP THEM ACHIEVE THE BEST POSSIBLE OUTCOMES. AS FUNDING OPPORTUNITIES CONTINUE, THE NBSP PROGRAM WILL CONTINUES TO ENSURE ALL INFANTS WHO ARE BORN IN NEW HAMPSHIRE ARE SCREENED FOR HERITABLE CONDITIONS. IN NEW HAMPSHIRE THERE ARE APPROXIMATELY 20/30 INFANTS IDENTIFIED EACH YEAR WITH A HERITABLE DISORDER. THE NBSP IS WELL POISED TO CONTINUE TO WORK SUCCESSFULLY WITH HOSPITALS, BIRTH CENTERS, SPECIALTY PROVIDERS, AND SPECIAL MEDICAL SERVICES TO ACHIEVE OUTCOMES THAT INCLUDE IMPROVED DOCUMENTATION OF FOLLOW-UP.  THE NBSP HAS WELL ESTABLISHED CONTRACTS WITH UNIVERSITY OF MASSACHUSETTS, LABORATORY AN OZ SYSTEMS TO CARRY OUT SURVEILLANCE ACTIVITIES. THE NBSP AIMS TO IMPROVE ITS WORK WITH SPECIALTY PROVIDERS AND EARLY SPECIAL MEDICAL SERVICES TO ASSURE INFANTS WHO ARE IDENTIFIED WITH A HERITABLE CONDITION HAVE ALL RESOURCES TO HELP THEM REACH THEIR FULL POTENTIAL.
STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM

STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM - ADDRESS: NEWBORN SCREENING PROGRAM, PO BOX 64899, ST. PAUL, MN 55164-0899 PROJECT DIRECTOR: JILL SIMONETTI CONTACT PHONE NUMBERS: 651-201-5469 EMAIL ADDRESS: JILL.SIMONETTI@STATE.MN.US  WEBSITE ADDRESS: HTTPS://WWW.HEALTH.STATE.MN.US/PEOPLE/NEWBORNSCREENING  THE MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (MDH), TOGETHER WITH MANY STAKEHOLDER PARTNERS, WILL DECREASE HEALTH DISPARITIES AND IMPROVE HEALTH INEQUITIES IN THE OUT OF HOSPITAL BIRTH COMMUNITY BY PROVIDING POINT OF CARE SCREENING EQUIPMENT TO MIDWIVES AND OTHER BIRTH PROVIDERS ATTENDING OUT OF HOSPITAL BIRTHS. ADDITIONALLY, EDUCATION AND TRAINING WILL BE CREATED TO PROVIDE CULTURALLY RELEVANT NEWBORN SCREENING INFORMATION, DECREASE MISSING POINT OF CARE SCREENING RATES WITHIN THIS COMMUNITY, AND STRENGTHEN PARTNERSHIPS THROUGHOUT THE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM. THESE SERVICES WILL HELP INCREASE ACCESS TO NEWBORN SCREENING AND FOLLOW UP FOR THE OUT OF HOSPITAL BIRTH COMMUNITY. MDH ALSO AIMS TO EXPAND ITS CURRENT BLOOD SPOT SCREENING CAPABILITIES TO INCLUDE RECENT RECOMMENDED UNIFORM SCREENING PANEL ADDITIONS, MUCOPOLYSACCHARIDOSIS TYPE II AND GUANIDINOACETATE METHYLTRANSFERASE DEFICIENCY, BY ADDING ADDITIONAL TARGETS TO EXISTING SCREENING METHODS. IDENTIFYING BABIES WITH THESE CONDITIONS WILL GIVE THEM ACCESS TO EARLY DIAGNOSIS AND TREATMENT TO IMPROVE THEIR HEALTH OUTCOMES. MDH WILL ALSO ENGAGE WITH FAMILIES OF INFANTS AND CHILDREN WITH CONGENITAL CYTOMEGALOVIRUS (CCMV) IDENTIFIED THROUGH NEWBORN SCREENING TO LEARN FROM THEIR EXPERIENCES. CURRENTLY, FAMILY EXPERIENCE WITH THE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM IS NOT SYSTEMATICALLY ASSESSED. THE NEED EXISTS TO COLLECT THIS DATA IN A WAY THAT REFLECTS THE DIVERSITY OF EXPERIENCES AND CAN BE USED TO ADDRESS HEALTH INEQUITIES AND ASSURE NEWBORN SCREENING FOLLOW-UP CENTERS THE VOICES OF CHILDREN AND FAMILIES. THE HIGHER PREVALENCE OF CCMV INFECTION, AS COMPARED TO OTHER NEWBORN SCREENING CONDITIONS, WILL ALLOW MDH TO SURVEY A DIVERSE GROUP OF FAMILIES, UNDERSTAND T HE UNIQUE NEEDS AND COMMON EXPERIENCES OF DIFFERENT COMMUNITIES, AND ULTIMATELY DEVELOP A FRAMEWORK FOR SHORT-TERM AND LONGITUDINAL FOLLOW-UP THAT CENTERS FAMILY EXPERIENCE. THE INFORMATION GATHERED FROM FAMILIES, AS WELL AS PROVIDER AND PARTNER OBSERVATIONS, WILL BE USED TO DEVELOP A GENERALIZED FAMILY ENGAGEMENT PROCESS AND SYSTEMATIC FAMILY EXPERIENCE ASSESSMENT TOOLS FOR REPLICATION AND BROAD DISSEMINATION WHEN IMPLEMENTING ANY NEWBORN SCREENING CONDITION. FINALLY, BASED ON THE DATA COLLECTED, MDH WILL ALSO IMPLEMENT A QUALITY IMPROVEMENT PROJECT TO ADDRESS AT LEAST ONE FOLLOW-UP AREA IN NEED OF IMPROVEMENT.

STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM - THE INDIANA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (IDOH) RECOGNIZES SEVERAL IMMEDIATE NEEDS TO IMPROVE THE STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM. INDIANA IS COMMITTED TO IMPROVING THE EFFICIENCY AND TIMELINESS OF RESULT REPORTING, IMPROVING THE SHORT-TERM FOLLOW-UP PROCESS, AND ESTABLISHING A LONG-TERM FOLLOW-UP PROCESS. IDOH BELIEVES THE STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM (NBS PROPEL) HRSA FUNDING OPPORTUNITY IS CRITICAL FOR INDIANA’S CURRENT MOMENTUM TOWARDS SUSTAINABLY IMPROVING THE HEALTH OUTCOMES OF INDIVIDUALS AT RISK FOR AND LIVING WITH HERITABLE CONDITIONS FROM NEWBORN SCREENING.  IN THE LAST SEVERAL YEARS, INDIANA’S NEWBORN SCREENING PROGRAM HAS SEEN AN EMERGING NEED TO ADDRESS TIMELINESS OF SPECIMEN COLLECTION, SCREENING, AND RESULT REPORTING. IN ORDER TO OVERCOME THIS CHALLENGE, INDIANA BELIEVES INTEROPERABILITY BETWEEN THE HOSPITAL SYSTEM, THE NEWBORN SCREENING LAB, AND THE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH WILL REDUCE TIME DELAYS. INDIANA HAS TAKEN STEPS TO ACHIEVE INTEROPERABILITY BY PARTICIPATING IN THE HRSA FUNDED INNOVATIONS IN NEWBORN SCREENING INTEROPERABILITY PROJECT AND ECHO CALLS. INDIANA PLANS TO IMPLEMENT THE DEVELOPED INTEROPERABILITY ROADMAP TO ACHIEVE MORE TIMELY SPECIMEN COLLECTION, SCREENING, AND RESULT REPORTING.  ACHIEVING INTEROPERABILITY WILL ALSO IMPROVE SHORT-TERM FOLLOW-UP AND ALLOW FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF LONG-TERM FOLLOW-UP IN INDIANA. CURRENTLY, ALL HOSPITALS ARE REQUIRED TO MANUALLY ENTER EXCEPTIONS TO SCREENING MONTHLY INTO A DATA SYSTEM AT THE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH WHICH ALLOWS THE DEPARTMENT TO FOLLOW-UP AND ENSURE ALL NEWBORNS RECEIVE MANDATED SCREENING. HOWEVER, THE CURRENT PROCESS INCLUDES UP TO A 45-DAY DELAY IN REPORTING AN EXCEPTION, SEVERELY IMPACTING THE TIMELINESS OF FOLLOWING-UP WITH INFANTS WHO WERE NOT SCREENED. ADDITIONALLY, ACHIEVING INTEROPERABILITY WILL PROVIDE NEWBORN SCREENING RESULTS DIRECTLY TO PROVIDERS THROUGH INDIANA HEALTH INFORMATION EXCHANGE INTERFACES ALREADY IN USE BY PROVIDERS ELIMINATING THE NEED FOR PROVIDERS TO CHECK MULTIPLE DATA SYSTEMS FOR RESULTS.  THE INDIANA NEWBORN SCREENING PROGRAM IS FACING ADDITIONAL CHALLENGES WITHIN THE SHORT-TERM FOLLOW-UP AND LONG-TERM FOLLOW-UP PROCESSES.  INDIANA AIMS TO IMPROVE THE CURRENT SHORT-TERM FOLLOW-UP PROCESS AND HEALTH OUTCOMES FOR PATIENTS IDENTIFIED WITH OR AT RISK FOR NEWBORN SCREENING CONDITION. THE STRATEGIES TO IMPROVING SHORT-TERM FOLLOW-UP INCLUDE DEVELOPMENT OF INTEROPERABLE SYSTEMS, EXPANSION OF PRENATAL AND FAMILY EDUCATION, IMPROVEMENT OF THE DATA FROM FUNDED CARE COORDINATION PARTNERS, TRANSLATION OF EDUCATION MATERIALS INTO OTHER PRIMARY SPOKEN LANGUAGES, AND IMPROVEMENT OF MONTHLY HOSPITAL REPORTING. INDIANA RECOGNIZES THAT IMPROVEMENTS IN HEALTH OUTCOMES CANNOT BE MADE WITHOUT A LONG-TERM FOLLOW-UP PROCESS. INDIANA AIMS TO LAUNCH LONG-TERM FOLLOW-UP FOR ONE CONDITION INITIALLY WITH THE GOAL TO EXPAND ONCE BEST PRACTICES ARE DEVELOPED. THROUGHOUT THE ACTIVITIES TO IMPROVE THE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM, INDIANA WILL EMPOWER FAMILIES TO ACTIVELY ENGAGE WITH THE NEWBORN SCREENING PROGRAM TO ENSURE THAT THE WORK CONDUCTED IS MEANINGFUL TO THE POPULATIONS SERVED. IMPROVEMENTS MADE TO BOTH AREAS OF FOLLOW-UP WILL ULTIMATELY LEAD TO IMPROVED HEALTH EQUITY AND ACCESS TO SERVICES ALONG WITH BETTER QUALITY OF LIFE FOR INDIVIDUALS AND FAMILIES AT RISK FOR OR LIVING WITH HERITABLE CONDITIONS.  IDOH WILL BE RESOURCEFUL AND INNOVATIVE IN ITS APPROACH WHILE FULFILLING ALL REQUIREMENTS FOR THE STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM HRSA FUNDING, IF GRANTED THE OPPORTUNITY. IDOH WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE NATIONAL CENTER FOR NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM EXCELLENCE RECIPIENT AS REQUIRED. IDOH WILL IMPLEMENT INTEROPERABILITY AND IMPROVE TIMELINESS, SHORT-TERM FOLLOW-UP, AND LONG-TERM FOLLOW-UP TO BETTER SERVE NEWBORNS AND FAMILIES ACROSS INDIANA. ULTIMATELY, LEADING TO BETTER HEALTH OUTCOMES FOR PEOPLE AT RISK FOR AND LIVING WITH HERITABLE CONDITIONS IN INDIANA.

STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM - THE OREGON STATE PUBLIC HEALTH LABORATORY (OSPHL) NEWBORN BLOODSPOT SCREENING PROGRAM PROPOSAL, IMPLEMENTATION OF NEW CONDITIONS TO THE OREGON NEWBORN SCREENING PANEL, FOR THE HRSA NBS PROPEL FUNDING OPPORTUNITY (HRSA-23-065) ADDRESSES TWO DISTINCT GOALS: CREATION OF A COMPREHENSIVE IMPLEMENTATION GUIDE FOR NEW CONDITIONS AND INITIATION OF SCREENING FOR MUCOPOLYSACCHARIDOSIS TYPE II (MPSII).  THE OSPHL RECENTLY ADDED SEVERAL CONDITIONS TO ITS SCREENING PANEL BASED UPON THE RECOMMENDATION OF THE SECRETARY’S ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON HERITABLE DISORDERS IN NEWBORNS AND CHILDREN (SACHDNC).  WHILE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF SCREENING WAS SUCCESSFUL, THE PROCESS TOOK ON AVERAGE OVER 5 YEARS TO COMPLETE FOR A GIVEN CONDITION.  ADDITIONALLY, SEVERAL KEY COMPONENTS, SUCH AS EDUCATION AND SHORT-TERM FOLLOW-UP, WERE NOT AS THOROUGHLY PLANNED OR EXECUTED.  GIVEN THIS ASSESSMENT, THE OSPHL INTENDS TO CREATE A COMPREHENSIVE GUIDE FOR IMPLEMENTATION OF NEW CONDITIONS TO ITS SCREENING PANEL. THIS GUIDE WOULD ADDRESS ALL THE KEY COMPONENTS REQUIRED FOR SCREENING AND CASE MANAGEMENT AND INCLUDE BEST PRACTICES OBTAINED THROUGH REFLECTION ON PAST EXPERIENCES AND ENGAGEMENT WITH HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS AND FAMILIES.  TO EVALUATE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF THE GUIDE, OSPHL WILL USE IT TO IMPLEMENT SCREENING FOR MUCOPOLYSACCHARIDOSIS TYPE II (MPSII).  OSPHL’S PROPOSAL IS GROUNDED IN THE THEMES OF IMPLEMENTATION SCIENCE, ADDRESSING METRICS AND MONITORING, EVALUATION AND FEEDBACK, AND CONTINUOUS QUALITY IMPROVEMENT. THE LASTING BENEFITS OF THE NBS PROPEL FUNDING OPPORTUNITY IS THE ADDITION OF MPSII TO OREGON’S SCREENING PANEL TO SERVE ITS NEWEST CITIZENS AND AN IMPLEMENTATION GUIDE THAT CAN BE USED FOR FUTURE CONDITIONS.

STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM - THE CONNECTICUT NEWBORN SCREENING (CT NBS) PROGRAM IS BASED OUT OF THE STATE PUBLIC HEALTH LABORATORY (SPHL) WHICH HOUSES THE NBS LABORATORY AND THE NBS FOLLOW-UP AND TRACKING UNIT (NBSFU) COMPONENTS OF THE PROGRAM. THERE WERE 36,928 LIVE BIRTHS IN CT IN 2021. THE CT NBS PROGRAM RECEIVED A VALID NEWBORN SCREENING (NBS) SAMPLE FOR OVER NINETY-NINE PERCENT (>99.9%) OF ELIGIBLE NEWBORNS THAT SAME YEAR. CT NBS CONDUCTS BLOODSPOT SCREENING FOR MOST OF THE PRIMARY AND SECONDARY CONDITIONS THE NATIONAL RECOMMENDED UNIFORM SCREENING PANEL WITH THE EXCEPTION OF CYSTIC FIBROSIS (CF).  CF SCREENING IS CONDUCTED AT TWO UNIVERSITY LABORATORIES IN CT THAT DO NOT REPORT CF SCREENING RESULTS OR CONFIRMED CASE DATA TO THE CT NBS PROGRAM.  IT IS BELIEVED THAT DUE TO GAPS IN THE CURRENT SYSTEM, NOT ALL CT NEWBORNS ARE BEING SCREENED FOR  CF.  AN AMENDMENT TO CT GENERAL STATUTES (CGS) SEC. 19A-55E EFFECTIVE OCTOBER 1, 2021, NOW MANDATES THAT THE CF LABORATORIES REPORT THE NUMBER OF NEWBORN INFANTS SCREENED AND THE RESULTS OF SUCH TESTING, NOT LESS THAN ANNUALLY, TO THE DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH CURRENTLY THERE IS NO SYSTEM IN PLACE FOR THE REPORTING OF CF STATISTICS BY THE TESTING LABORATORIES TO THE CT NBS PROGRAM. BESIDES CF, THE ONLY OTHER RUSP DISORDERS DETECTABLE THROUGH BLOODSPOT SCREENING THAT THE CT NBS PROGRAM DOES NOT CURRENTLY SCREEN FOR ARE MPS-II AND GAMT DEFICIENCY. THE CT NPS CURRENTLY SCREENS FOR SICKLE CELL DISEASE AND SICKLE CELL TRAIT, BUT WE KNOW THAT THERE CONTINUE TO BE KNOWLEDGE GAPS PARTICULARLY FOR THOSE IN HIGHER RISK POPULATION IN CHILDBEARING YEARS REGARDING SICKLE CELL TRAIT STATUS.  BEING AWARE OF ONE’S SICKLE CELL TRAIT STATUS IS IMPORTANT DECREASE THE CHANGES OF A FUTURE CHILD BEING BORN WITH SICKLE CELL DISEASE.  LASTLY,  WE KNOW THAT NBS ONLY REACHES ITS FULL POTENTIAL WHEN IDENTIFIED INFANTS HAVE PROMPT ACCESS TO DIAGNOSTIC EVALUATIONS AND THEN, FOR THOSE CONFIRMED WITH A DIAGNOSIS, HAVE ACCESS TO APPROPRIATE CARE ACROSS THEI R LIFESPAN.  NATIONALLY, LONG-TERM FOLLOW-UP (LTFU) IN NBS HAS BEEN INCONSISTENT. USING FUNDS FROM THIS GRANT, CT NBS PROGRAM PLANS TO (A) ESTABLISH A SYSTEM FOR COLLECTING CF SCREENING DATA AND DEVELOP A PLAN TO ADDRESS AREAS IN NEED OF IMPROVEMENT AND TO IMPLEMENT SCREENING FOR CF FOR THOSE INFANTS MISSED BY THE CURRENT SYSTEM (B) IMPLEMENT SCREENING FOR NEWLY ADDED MPS-II AND GAMPT DEFICIENCY (C) OPTIMIZE RESOURCES FOR PARENTS OF NEWBORNS  WITH SICKLE CELL TRAIT OR DISEASE) AND (D) CONTINUE DEVELOPMENT OF LTFU SYSTEMS.
STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM

STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM - PROJECT ABSTRACT  THE COLORADO NEWBORN BLOODSPOT SCREENING PROGRAM (CONBSP) IS A PART OF THE COLORADO STATE PUBLIC HEALTH LABORATORY WITHIN THE DIVISION OF DISEASE CONTROL AND PUBLIC HEALTH RESPONSE (DCPHR) AT THE COLORADO DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENT (CDPHE).  CONBSP HAS A TWO SCREEN TESTING ALGORITHM THAT PERFORMS SCREENING TESTS FOR ALL NEWBORNS ON AN OPT-OUT BASIS. ANNUALLY, THERE ARE APPROXIMATELY A TOTAL OF 68,000 BIRTHS IN COLORADO AND WYOMING.  THIS TRANSLATES INTO REPORTING MORE THAN 130,000 SAMPLES USING NINE DIFFERENT TESTING METHODS FOR MORE THAN 700,000 INDIVIDUAL TESTS ANNUALLY.  CONBSP PERFORMS TESTING SIX DAYS A WEEK WITH A STAFF OF 15 FULL TIME EMPLOYEES INCLUDING FOLLOW-UP STAFF. IN JANUARY 2020, THE CONBSP IMPLEMENTED SPINAL MUSCULAR ATROPHY (SMA) SCREENING.  IN MARCH OF 2021, THE COLORADO BOARD OF HEALTH APPROVED THE ADDITION OF GLYCOGEN STORAGE DISEASE TYPE II (POMPE), MUCOPOLYSACCHARIDOSIS TYPE I (MPS1) AND X-LINKED ADRENOLEUKODYSTROPHY (X-ALD) TO THE CONBSP PANEL ALIGNING IT WITH THE HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES RECOMMENDED UNIFORM SCREENING PANEL (RUSP). POMPE AND MPS1 VALIDATIONS WERE COMPLETED IN 2022 WITH POPULATION BASED TESTING IMPLEMENTED IN JUNE OF 2022.  THE X-ALD FIRST TIER VALIDATION WAS COMPLETED IN LATE 2022.  CONTRACTING FOR SECOND TIER TESTING FOR X-ALD IS STILL IN PROCESS AS OF FEBRUARY 2023 AND CONTINUES TO DELAY IMPLEMENTATION OF POPULATION BASED TESTING.  THE CONBSP ALIGNMENT WITH THE RUSP IN 2021 AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THOSE DISORDERS HAS HIGHLIGHTED THE NEED FOR DEDICATED STAFFING AND PROCEDURES TO ENSURE TIMELY ADDITION OF NEW DISORDERS. FOR FOCUS AREA ONE, THIS GRANT OPPORTUNITY WILL FUND A QA/QC SCIENTIST AND LABORATORY TECHNOLOGIST WHO WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR DETERMINING BEST TESTING METHODS, INSTRUMENTATION, WORKFLOWS, AND PERFORM VALIDATION TESTING.  A KEY ACTIVITY FOR THIS STAFF WILL BE TO DOCUMENT BEST PRACTICES, REQUIREMENTS, TIMELINES AND ROADBLOCKS FOR AN OVERALL DISORDER IMPLEMEN TATION GUIDE.  FOR FOCUS AREA TWO, THE ADDITION OF A PROJECT COORDINATOR WILL PROVIDE A DEDICATED EDUCATION AND FOLLOW-UP SPECIALIST TO CREATE A MORE EFFICIENT PROCESS FOR THE ADDITION OF NEW DISORDERS AND ONGOING QA IMPROVEMENTS. THE PROJECT COORDINATOR WILL BE RESPONSIBLE FOR DEVELOPING STAKEHOLDER SURVEYS, EDUCATIONAL MATERIAL, INFORMATION PATHWAYS, DATA COLLECTION PROCESSES, AND DATA DISTRIBUTION WITH CI INTERNATIONAL.  TOGETHER, THE PROJECT COORDINATOR AND CI INTERNATIONAL WILL DEVELOP, DOCUMENT, AND EVALUATE THESE PROCESSES TO CREATE AN EDUCATION AND FOLLOW-UP IMPLEMENTATION GUIDE. THE CONBSP GOALS ARE TO ADD THREE TO FIVE DISORDERS, ADD ONE TO THREE SECOND TIER TESTING METHODS, DEVELOP TIMELY NEW DISORDER EDUCATION, AND CREATE IMPLEMENTATION GUIDES BY THE END OF THE GRANT TERM. THE INTEGRATION OF THE QA/QC SCIENTIST, LABORATORY TECHNOLOGIST, AND PROJECT COORDINATOR WILL PROVIDE THE REQUIRED RESOURCES TO COMPLETE THESE GOALS.

STATE NEWBORN SCREENING SYSTEM PRIORITIES PROGRAM - NEWBORN SCREENING (NBS) IS A CRITICAL PUBLIC HEALTH PROGRAM IN ARIZONA WITH A VISION TO PROTECT AND PROMOTE THE HEALTH AND WELLNESS OF ALL INDIVIDUALS AND COMMUNITIES IN OUR STATE. THE PROGRAM IS HOUSED IN THE ARIZONA STATE PUBLIC HEALTH LABORATORY, A BUREAU OF ARIZONA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH SERVICES. THE PROGRAM’S MISSION IS TO DETECT UNCOMMON OR RARE CONDITIONS THAT WOULD AFFECT A CHILD’S LONG-TERM HEALTH OR SURVIVAL. THE ARIZONA NBS PROGRAM IS APPLYING FOR HRSA-23-065 (NBS PROPEL) IN ORDER TO ENHANCE, IMPROVE, AND EXPAND OUR CURRENT SYSTEM; IMPROVE ON OUR TRANSIT TIME (TIME FROM SAMPLE COLLECTION TO RECEIPT AT THE LABORATORY) AND TURN-AROUND TIME (TIME FROM RECEIPT OF SAMPLE TO REPORTING OF RESULTS); SUPPORT IMPLEMENTATION OF NEW CONDITIONS ADDED TO THE RECOMMENDED UNIVERSAL SCREENING PANEL (RUSP) WITHIN 2 YEARS OF THEIR ADDITION; AND INCREASE ACCESS TO TREATMENT AND FOLLOW-UP ACTIVITIES FOR INDIVIDUALS AND THEIR FAMILIES WITH CONDITIONS IDENTIFIED THROUGH OUR PROGRAM. ADDITIONALLY, THIS FUNDING ALSO GIVES US AN OPPORTUNITY TO ESTABLISH A LONG-TERM FOLLOW-UP (LTFU) PROGRAM TO ENSURE THAT THOSE IDENTIFIED WITH NEWBORN SCREENING CONDITIONS HAVE ACCESS TO CARE AND RESOURCES AND ARE SUPPORTED THROUGHOUT THEIR LIFE COURSE. LONG-TERM SURVEILLANCE OF THE NBS PROGRAM IN ARIZONA IS IMPORTANT TO TRACK AND ENSURE HEALTH EQUITY AND SUCCESSFUL OUTCOMES OF THOSE DIAGNOSED WITH NBS CONDITIONS. LASTLY, THE INCORPORATION OF PARENT PARTNERS TO THE NBS PROGRAM AND THE LTFU ACTIVITIES WILL ENSURE THAT OBJECTIVES OF THIS PROJECT ARE CARRIED OUT WITH THE HIGHEST REGARD TO FAMILY INVOLVEMENT AND CHOICE. THEY ARE KEY TO DEVELOPING SUPPORTS AND SERVICES TO SUPPORT THEIR NEWBORN WITH LIVING WITH A CONDITION IDENTIFIED THROUGH NEWBORN SCREENING.

HEALTHY TOMORROWS PARTNERSHIP FOR CHILDREN PROGRAM - THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROVIDE ACCESS TO HIGH QUALITY, CULTURALLY RELEVANT, EVIDENCE-BASED CARE FOR CHILDREN AND THEIR FAMILIES FOR THE PURPOSES OF OPTIMIZING THEIR WELL-BEING AND LAYING THE FOUNDATION FOR POSITIVE HEALTH OUTCOMES DURING THEIR ADULT YEARS. THE 10-LEADING CAUSE OF DEATH IN ALABAMA (AL) RESPECTIVELY ARE HEART DISEASE, CANCER, COVID-19, CHRONIC LOWER RESPIRATORY DISEASES, STROKE, ALZHEIMER’S DISEASE, ACCIDENTS, DIABETES, INFLUENZA/PNEUMONIA, AND KIDNEY DISEASE (CDC, 2022). EXCEPT FOR THE RESPIRATORY ILLNESSES, ALL THE DISEASES ARE IMPACTED BY LIFESTYLE CHOICES SUCH AS NUTRITION AND EXERCISE. POOR HEALTH DURING THE CHILD AND ADOLESCENT YEARS CONTRIBUTES TO POOR HEALTH OUTCOMES AS AN ADULT, POOR QUALITY OF LIFE, AND PREMATURE DEATH.   WHEN COMPARED TO THE REST OF THE U.S, ALABAMA’S CHILDREN AND ADOLESCENTS HAVE MORE OBESITY, AND THE PROBLEM IS BECOMING WORSE YEAR OVER YEAR. HEALTHY MEALS AND EXERCISE ARE KNOWN TO CONTRIBUTE TO HEALTHY WEIGHT, DECREASED CHRONIC DISEASE AND POSITIVE HEALTH OUTCOMES. YET WE KNOW THAT NUTRITION AND EXERCISE ARE STRONGLY INFLUENCED BY SOCIAL DETERMINANTS. CHILDREN FROM UNDER RESOURCED COMMUNITIES STRUGGLE WITH ADEQUATE AND HEALTHY NUTRITION AND A BUILT ENVIRONMENT THAT IS OFTEN NOT CONDUCIVE FOR OUTDOOR ACTIVITIES THAT PROMOTE EXERCISE. WE INTEND TO USE THE LIFE COURSE MODEL WITH A COLLECTIVE IMPACT FOCUS TO DEVELOP AN UPSTREAM PREVENTION PROGRAM TO HELP CHILDREN ESTABLISH POSITIVE HEALTH BEHAVIORS AND INCREASE THEIR ACCESS TO PREVENTIVE HEALTH CARE.  OUR PLAN IS TO ESTABLISH A WELLNESS INITIATIVE IN TITUSVILLE THAT WILL HELP CHILDREN AND THEIR FAMILIES LEARN HOW TO INCORPORATE HEALTHY EATING AND EXERCISE INTO THEIR DAILY ROUTINE. WE DO THIS BY ADDRESSING FOOD INSECURITY AND INCREASING ACCESS TO HEALTHY FOODS WITH A MOBILE MARKET, PROVIDING NUTRITION EDUCATION WITH EVIDENCE-BASED WEIGHT MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS DESIGNED FOR MINORITY COMMUNITIES FROM THE SNAP-ED TOOL KIT, AND INCREASING ACCESS TO SAF E, AGE APPROPRIATE PHYSICAL ACTIVITY THROUGH AFTERSCHOOL PROGRAMS THAT TAKES PLACE AT SIXTH AVENUE BAPTIST CHURCH, THE LOCAL ELEMENTARY SCHOOL AND COMMUNITY RECREATION CENTER. BECAUSE MANY OF THE FOODS THAT CAUSE DENTAL DECAY ALSO CAUSE OBESITY, GRANT ACTIVITIES WILL INCLUDE ORAL HEALTH EDUCATION THROUGH THE LIFESPAN, SURVEILLANCE SCREENINGS FOR CARIES AND REFERRAL.

HEALTHY TOMORROWS PARTNERSHIP FOR CHILDREN PROGRAM - THE TEEN XPRESS MOBILE HEALTHCARE PROGRAM HAS OPERATED UNDER ORLANDO HEALTH ARNOLD PALMER HOSPITAL FOR CHILDREN FOR OVER 20 YEARS. IN RESPONSE TO THE INCREASING DEMAND FOR HEALTHCARE SERVICES FOR CHILDREN FROM IMMIGRANT FAMILIES IN CENTRAL FLORIDA, THIS INITIATIVE SEEKS TO ENHANCE THE PROGRAM'S CAPACITY TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH AND WELL-BEING OF TEENS FROM THIS UNDERSERVED POPULATION. TEEN XPRESS WILL DEVELOP STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS WITH COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS WITH THE APPROPRIATE RESOURCES TO SERVE CHILDREN FROM IMMIGRANT FAMILIES, PARTICIPATE IN ANNUAL TRAINING TO PROMOTE THE CULTURAL COMPETENCY OF THE SERVICES DELIVERED, DEVELOP CULTURALLY AND LINGUISTICALLY APPROPRIATE EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS, AND PROVIDE COMPREHENSIVE, MEDICAL, MENTAL HEALTH AND CASE MANAGEMENT SERVICES. THE CASE MANAGEMENT SERVICES IN PARTICULAR ARE A FOCAL POINT FOR THE PROJECT AS WE SEEK TO ENSURE CHILDREN FROM IMMIGRANT FAMILIES AND THEIR CAREGIVERS ARE CONNECTED TO MEDICAL AND SOCIAL SERVICES IN THE COMMUNITY. CASE MANAGERS WILL IDENTIFY SERVICE PROVIDERS WITH THE CAPACITY TO SERVE THE IMMIGRANT POPULATION AND SUPPORT BOTH THE PATIENTS AND THE SERVICE PROVIDERS IN IMPROVING THE UTILIZATION OF CARE. FINALLY, THE PROJECT'S ADVISORY BOARD WILL INCLUDE REPRESENTATIVES FROM ORLANDO HEALTH, PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS, AND PATIENT FAMILIES TO OFFER RECOMMENDATIONS TO THE PROGRAM. THE GOAL IS TO SERVE A MINIMUM OF 200 CHILDREN FROM IMMIGRANT FAMILIES EACH YEAR IDENTIFIED VIA STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS AND INCREASE THEIR ACCESS TO MEDICAL AND SOCIAL SERVICES.

HEALTHY TOMORROWS PARTNERSHIP FOR CHILDREN PROGRAM - BALLAD HEALTH/MOUNTAIN STATES 400 N STATE OF FRANKLIN RD, JOHNSON CITY, TN 37604 TARA CHADWELL 423-431-4891; 423-302-3448 FAX TARA.CHADWELL@BALLADHEALTH.ORG WWW.BALLADHEALTH.ORG $250,000  PROBLEM TRANSITIONS FROM FAMILIAR PEDIATRIC CARE PROVIDERS TO ADULT CARE CAN BE UNSETTLING FOR CHILDREN/ADOLESCENTS WITH SPECIAL HEALTH CARE NEEDS AND FAMILIES AS THE CHILD AGES TO ADULTHOOD, AND COORDINATION OF CARE CAN ALSO BE COMPLEX WITHOUT ASSISTANCE.    GOALS AND OBJECTIVES SERVE A MINIMUM OF 70 CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL HEALTH CARE NEEDS ANNUALLY  -	ESTABLISH A NEW PROGRAM TO SUPPORT FAMILIES/CHILDREN WITH SPECIAL HEALTH CARE NEEDS TRANSITIONING FROM PEDIATRIC TO ADULT CARE BY HIRING A TRANSITION COORDINATOR TO ASSIST WITH THESE TRANSITIONS; INCREASE ACCESS TO PREVENTIVE CARE/SERVICES IN THE MEDICAL HOME; INCREASE ENGAGEMENT IN SHARED DECISION-MAKING; ASSIST WITH STRUCTURAL AND SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH (SSDOHS); AND COORDINATE CARE TO OPTIMIZE HEALTH, QUALITY OF LIFE, AND WELL-BEING  -	ESTABLISH A REGIONAL ADVISORY BOARD OF FAMILIES OF PATIENTS, REGIONAL STAKEHOLDERS, AND CARE TEAM MEMBERS TO PROVIDE PROJECT OVERSIGHT, DISSEMINATE FINDINGS, AND CREATE A SUSTAINABILITY PLAN  -	IMPROVE COORDINATION WITH PROVIDERS; PALLIATIVE CARE; MEDICAL HOMES; FOSTER CARE; AND EMERGENCY ROOMS TO IMPROVE PATIENT/FAMILY-CENTERED CARE; AND SCHOOLS TO KEEP HOSPITALIZED CHILDREN CURRENT ON ASSIGNMENTS AND ADDRESS 504 AND INDIVIDUALIZED EDUCATION PLANS (IEP)   1. TRANSITION COORDINATOR HIRED WITHIN 60 DAYS OF NOTICE OF AWARD (NOA) 2. REGIONAL ADVISORY BOARD FORMED WITHIN 90 DAYS OF NOA COMPOSED OF MEMBERS REFLECTIVE OF CHILDREN/FAMILIES SERVED 3. UTILIZE STATE TITLE V MCH NEEDS ASSESSMENTS, ACTION PLANS, AND INTERNAL DATA TO GUIDE THE PROJECT, WITH DATA FINDINGS DISCUSSED MONTHLY AT REGIONAL ADVISORY BOARD MEETINGS 4. 50% INCREASE ANNUALLY OF FAMILIES ENGAGED IN SHARED DECISION-MAKING VIA SHARED PLANS OF CARE AS MEASURED BY CONSUMER ASSESSMENT OF HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS AND SYST EMS (CAHPS) HEALTH PLAN SURVEY 5. 100% OF ENROLLED CHILDREN HAVE A MEDICAL HOME BY YEAR 5 AS MEASURED BY PEDIATRIC INTEGRATED CARE SURVEY (PICS) 6. WORKFORCE TRAINING PROVIDED QUARTERLY TO RELEVANT PARTNERS ON PEDIATRIC TO ADULT CARE TRANSITIONS, AND TO SCHOOLS ON IEP AND 504 PLAN CHANGES AS EACH CHILD AGES UP  7. SUSTAINABILITY PLAN CREATED BY YEAR 5  8. DISSEMINATE INFORMATION AND RESULTS/OUTCOMES ANNUALLY  9. FORM AT LEAST THREE NEW, COLLABORATIVE RELATIONSHIPS WITHIN 12 MONTHS OF NOA 10. PROVIDE COMMUNITY RESOURCE INVENTORIES TAILORED TO EACH FAMILY’S SSDOH NEEDS WITHIN 30 DAYS OF ENROLLMENT; INCLUDE WARM HANDOFFS TO SERVICES 11. EXPAND USE OF TELEHEALTH AND ELECTRONIC COLLABORATIVE CARE PLANS; MEASURED ANNUALLY BY NUMBER OF APPOINTMENTS AND PLANS CREATED  METHODOLOGY EVIDENCE-BASED STRATEGIES INCLUDE THE BIOPSYCHOSOCIAL MODEL, CHRONIC CARE MODEL, AND SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH MODEL WITH INTEGRATED, TEAM-BASED CARE CENTERED AROUND A COLLABORATIVE CARE PLAN THAT INCLUDES A CARE MAP, CARE NOTEBOOK, SHARED PLAN OF CARE, AND YOUTH-TO-ADULT CARE TRANSITION WORKBOOK   COORDINATION THE TRANSITION COORDINATOR WILL UTILIZE A COLLABORATIVE CARE PLAN STANDARDIZED AMONG PROVIDERS TO HELP WITH COORDINATING VISITS AND PROVIDING PATIENT- AND FAMILY-CENTERED CARE (THE PLAN INCLUDES HEALTH HISTORY AND MEDICATION INFORMATION); AND WILL COORDINATE WITH SCHOOLS TO KEEP STUDENTS CURRENT ON ASSIGNMENTS AND/OR ADVOCATE FOR IEP AND 504 PLAN CHANGES  EVALUATION MODELS EVALUATED FOR SUCCESS AT REGIONAL ADVISORY BOARD MEETINGS SO CHILDREN/ADOLESCENTS AND FAMILIES HAVE DIRECT INPUT.  PROCESS AND OUTCOME MEASURES USED TO GAUGE PROGRESS TOWARD STATED GOALS. DATA USED TO MAKE CHANGES TO THE PROJECT BASED ON EVALUATION RESULTS FROM THE CONTINUOUS QUALITY IMPROVEMENT (CQI) “PLAN-DO-STUDY-ACT” MODEL.  OTHER EVALUATION METHODS INCLUDE CONSUMER ASSESSMENT OF HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS AND SYSTEMS (CAHPS) HEALTH PLAN SURVEYS; PRESS-GANEY PATIENT SURVEYS; AND PEDIATRIC INTEGRATED CARE SURVEY (PICS) IN TERVIEWS

HEALTHY TOMORROWS PARTNERSHIP FOR CHILDREN PROGRAM - THE PURPOSE OF MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH CONSORTIUM’S (MCHC) PROPOSED FAMILY HEALTH PROMOTION INITIATIVE (FHPI) IS TO INCREASE AWARENESS OF AND ACCESS TO HEALTH CARE AND PREVENTION SERVICES IN CHESTER COUNTY, PENNSYLVANIA AMONG HEALTH AND SOCIAL SERVICE PROVIDERS OF MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH (MCH) POPULATIONS AND CONSUMERS. THIS INITIATIVE WILL SUPPORT ACTIVITIES CARRIED OUT BY MCHC'S MANAGER OF OUTREACH AND COMMUNITY RELATIONS AND COMMUNITY HEALTH SUPPORT COORDINATOR, WHO WILL IMPLEMENT BRIGHT FUTURES CURRICULUM INTO EXISTING HOME-VISITING PROGRAM TOOLS, TRAIN STAFF ON AN ONGOING BASIS, AND ENHANCE OUTREACH AND PROMOTION OF PREVENTION SERVICES THAT MCHC PROVIDES. OVERSIGHT AND SUPPORT WILL BE FROM MCHC'S DIRECTOR OF PROGRAMS, DIRECTOR OF DEVELOPMENT AND COMMUNICATIONS, AND THE PROJECT ADIVSORY BOARD.

HEALTHY TOMORROWS PARTNERSHIP FOR CHILDREN PROGRAM - MARY’S CENTER’S SOCIAL CHANGE MODEL INTEGRATES HEALTH CARE WITH PSYCHOSOCIAL SUPPORTS, AND THE PROJECT WE PROPOSE IN THIS APPLICATION FOCUSES THAT INTEGRATED APPROACH ON OUR CHILD AND ADOLESCENT PROGRAMMING, BUILDING ON OUR CURRENTLY FUNDED TEEN HEALTH PROJECT TO ADDRESS BEHAVIORAL HEALTH NEEDS AMONG A BROADER RANGE OF AGES. YOUNG PEOPLE WHO HAVE SUFFERED ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES HAVE LESS HEALTHY COPING MECHANISMS AND ARE MORE PRONE TO TAKE CHANCES AND/OR SEEK SELF-MEDICATION OR PARTICIPATE IN BEHAVIORS WHICH CAN LEAD TO UNINTENDED PREGNANCIES AND STDS. THE PROPOSED PROJECT WILL BUILD ON OUR EXISTING CHILD AND ADOLESCENT HEALTH SERVICES TO ADDRESS THE BEHAVIORAL HEALTH NEEDS IN OUR PEDIATRIC/TEEN POPULATION BY STRENGTHENING OUR WORKFLOW FOR PEDIATRICIANS’ SCREENING OF OUR CHILDREN AND ADOLESCENTS THROUGH IMPROVEMENTS IN SCREENING CAPACITY.  USING EVIDENCE-INFORMED SCREENING TOOLS FOR DEPRESSION AND ANXIETY THAT ARE AGE APPROPRIATE, WE AIM TO IDENTIFY THOSE CHILDREN WHO WOULD BENEFIT FROM BEHAVIORAL OR SOCIAL HEALTH SUPPORTS TO MEET THEIR NEEDS AND PREVENT LONG TERM ANXIETY, DEPRESSION OR MORE SERIOUS BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CONCERNS. FAMILY SUPPORT WORKERS ARE INCLUDED IN THE PROGRAMMING MODEL TO LINK YOUTH AND THEIR FAMILIES TO THE APPROPRIATE CARE AND CORRELATED SOCIAL SUPPORTS AND EDUCATIONAL NEEDS.  THIS NEW EFFORT TO INCLUDE BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES IN OUR COMPREHENSIVE PEDIATRIC CARE PROGRAM WILL CONNECT EXISTING HEALTHY TOMORROWS WORK TO OUR NETWORK OF SCHOOL-BASED MENTAL HEALTH CLINICS, TO OUR INTERNAL EARLY-CHILDHOOD BEHAVIORAL HEALTH PROGRAM, AS WELL AS TO OUR CO-LOCATED BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES. THESE ADDITIONS WILL INCREASE OUR CAPACITY TO OFFER BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES AT OUR COMPREHENSIVE CLINICS IN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA. EVERY TEEN WHO COMES TO ONE OF OUR CLINICS OR ENTERS AFTER-SCHOOL OR SUMMER PROGRAMMING MEETS WITH A FAMILY SUPPORT WORKER FOR AN INTAKE PROCESS THAT INCLUDES SCREENING FOR DEPRESSION USING THE PHQ-2 AND PHQ-9 SCREENING TOOLS, AS WELL AS SCREENING FOR ANXIETY, TOBACCO, ALCOHOL AND DRUG USE, AND INTIMATE PARTNER VIOLENCE.  ANYONE FOUND TO BE IN NEED OF INDIVIDUAL OR FAMILY SUPPORT WILL BE REFERRED TO A VARIETY OF EVIDENCE-BASED AND EVIDENCE-INFORMED PROGRAMS OFFERED BY MARY’S CENTER (OR TO EXTERNAL SUPPORTS WHERE NECESSARY). WHEN APPROPRIATE, THE SAMHSA EVIDENCE-BASED APPROACH, SBIRT (SCREENING, BRIEF INTERVENTION, AND REFERRAL TO TREATMENT) IS USED, AND ALL OF OUR CLINICIANS AND FAMILY SUPPORT WORKERS ARE TRAINED IN THIS PROTOCOL.  PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES CENTER AROUND IDENTIFYING AND SUPPORTING CHILDREN AND TEENS WHO ARE EXPERIENCING DEPRESSION AND ANXIETY. THIS EFFORT ALIGNS WITH THE PURPOSE AND REQUIREMENT OF THE HEALTHY TOMORROWS PROGRAM AND FITS INTO MARY’S CENTER’S LARGER “SOCIAL CHANGE MODEL” OF MULTI-DIMENSIONAL, FAMILY-ORIENTED CARE.  GOALS OF THE PROPOSED PROJECT INCLUDE:  GOAL 1: INCREASE THE NUMBER OF CHILDREN AND ADOLESCENTS SCREENED FOR DEPRESSION AND ANXIETY GOAL 2: LINK CHILDREN AND YOUTH WITH A POSITIVE SCREENING FOR DEPRESSION AND ANXIETY TO A BEHAVIORAL HEALTH THERAPIST GOAL 3: LINK FAMILIES WHOSE CHILDREN ARE MANAGING DEPRESSION AND ANXIETY TO A FAMILY SUPPORT FOR ENGAGEMENT IN EDUCATIONAL AND OTHER SOCIAL SERVICES NEEDS GOAL 4: ENGAGE YOUTH MANAGING DEPRESSION AND ANXIETY WITH INTERNAL SUPPORT PROGRAMS

HEALTHY TOMORROWS PARTNERSHIP FOR CHILDREN PROGRAM - ADDRESS: 2010 CATON WAY SW, STE 102 OLYMPIA, WA 98502-8203  PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME: KATIE STOLL  CONTACT PHONE NUMBERS (VOICE, FAX): 844-743-6384 EXT 701, 844-813-3892  EMAIL ADDRESS: KATIE.STOLL@GENETICSUPPORTFOUNDATION.ORG  WEBSITE ADDRESS: HTTPS://GENETICSUPPORTFOUNDATION.ORG/  ACCESS TO GENETIC TESTING AND COUNSELING SAVES LIVES. A POSITIVE RESULT CAN DIRECT INDIVIDUALS WHO ARE PREGNANT OR PLANNING TO BECOME PREGNANT, AND CHILDREN AND THEIR FAMILIES TO PREVENTION, MONITORING, AND TREATMENT OPTIONS–REDUCING RISK AND INCREASING THE CHANCE FOR INCREASED LIFE AND SUCCESSFUL OUTCOME FOR CHILDREN WITH GENETIC CONDITIONS. HOWEVER, LOW-INCOME AND BLACK, INDIGENOUS, AND PEOPLE OF COLOR (BIPOC) COMMUNITIES IN THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST LACK ACCESS TO LIFE-SAVING GENETIC SERVICES.  IN RESPONSE TO THE NEED IDENTIFIED FOR EQUITABLE, ACCESSIBLE GENETIC SERVICES IN ALASKA, IDAHO, WASHINGTON, AND OREGON COMMUNITIES, GENETIC SUPPORT FOUNDATION (GSF) WILL IMPLEMENT A NEW NO-COST MODEL OF GENETIC COUNSELING THROUGH TELEHEALTH GENETIC SERVICES FOR LOW-INCOME AND BIPOC COMMUNITIES ACROSS THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST. GSF IS REQUESTING $50,000 FROM THE HRSA IN PROJECT YEAR 1, AND THEN $50,000 PER YEAR THROUGHOUT THE 5-YEAR CONTRACT, TO DELIVER THIS PROJECT. GSF WILL FOCUS ON SUPPORTING PATIENTS AT FEDERALLY QUALIFIED HEALTH CENTERS/COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTERS TO ENSURE WE ARE REACHING THE MOST UNDERSERVED POPULATIONS. WE DO NOT KNOW OF ANY SERVICES IN THE PACIFIC NORTHWEST CURRENTLY OFFERING FREE INDEPENDENT GENETIC COUNSELING TO PATIENTS WITH A FOCUS ON REACHING MARGINALIZED COMMUNITIES. GSF SEEKS TO CHANGE THIS. AND AS THE ONLY GENETIC COUNSELING NONPROFIT, OUR TEAM OF 13 EXPERIENCED BOARD-CERTIFIED GENETIC COUNSELORS PROVIDE SERVICES WITHOUT BIAS FROM COMMERCIAL ENTITIES THAT PROFIT FROM GENETIC TEST SALES.  IN ADDITION TO PROVIDING DIRECT GENETIC COUNSELING SERVICES, GSF WILL ALSO DELIVER A CONTINUING EDUCATION AND OUTREACH CAMPAIGN TO HEALTHCARE PROVIDERS AND SUPPORT STAFF WHO WORK AT FEDERALLY QUALIFIED HEALTH CENTERS/COMMUNITY HEALTH CENTERS THAT PROVIDE FAMILY PLANNING SERVICES, PRENATAL CARE, AND PEDIATRIC CARE. PRIMARY CARE PROVIDERS ARE OFTEN THE MAIN TOUCH POINT IN PROVIDING PATIENT INFORMATION AND COUNSELING REGARDING PRECONCEPTION AND PRENATAL GENETIC TESTING OPTIONS AS WELL AS PEDIATRIC GENETIC TESTING. PROVIDING PRIMARY CARE PROVIDERS WITH BEST PRACTICES AND INFORMATION AROUND GENETIC CONDITIONS, TESTING, AND COUNSELING WILL ENABLE THEM TO BETTER SUPPORT THE GROWING NEEDS OF THEIR PATIENTS AS GENETIC INFORMATION BECOMES INCREASINGLY IMPORTANT TO PATIENT CARE.  PROJECTED PROJECT IMPACTS INCLUDE SUPPORTING FAMILIES TO RECEIVE TIMELY AND ACCURATE INFORMATION THAT HELPS THEM MAKE INFORMED DECISIONS ABOUT THE HEALTH OF THEIR CHILDREN, LEADING TO: 1) INCREASED LIFE-EXPECTANCIES, 2) IMPROVED QUALITY OF LIFE AND LONG-TERM HEALTH OUTCOMES, AND 3) MORE COST-EFFECTIVE AND IMPROVED MEDICAL CARE–ULTIMATELY LEADING TO HEALTHIER CHILDREN AND HEALTHIER COMMUNITIES.

HEALTHY TOMORROWS PARTNERSHIP FOR CHILDREN PROGRAM - PROJECT TITLE: HEALTHY TOMORROWS PARTNERSHIP FOR CHILDREN PROGRAM (HTPCP) APPLICANT ORGANIZATION NAME: CENTRO DE SALUD LA COMUNIDAD DE SAN YSIDRO INC. DBA: SAN YSIDRO HEALTH ADDRESS: 1601 PRECISION PARK LANE, SAN DIEGO, CA 92173-1345 PROJECT DIRECTOR NAME: FATIMA MUÑOZ CONTACT PHONE NUMBER: 619.395.8455 EMAIL ADDRESS: FATIMA.MUNOZ@SYHEALTH.ORG WEBSITE ADDRESS: WWW.SYHEALTH.ORG PROGRAM FUNDS REQUESTED: $50,000 PER YEAR OF THE 2023–2028 PROJECT PERIOD NEEDS TO BE ADDRESSED: SAN YSIDRO HEALTH (SYHEALTH) IS REQUESTING HEALTHY TOMORROWS PARTNERSHIP FOR CHILDREN PROGRAM (HTPCP) GRANT FUNDS TO SUPPORT ITS PROPOSED LEARNING AND UNDERSTANDING THE NEED FOR INTEGRATED ADHERENCE (LUNITA) PROGRAM FOR CHILDREN & FAMILIES A.K.A LUNITA-EAST PROGRAM. THE PROPOSED LUNITA-EAST PROGRAM ADDRESSES THE NEED FOR COMPREHENSIVE, CULTURALLY, AND LINGUISTICALLY INCLUSIVE SERVICES FOR CHILDREN AGED 6-11 AND THEIR PARENTS/CAREGIVERS WHO RESIDE AND RECEIVE SERVICES IN SAN DIEGO COUNTY’S EAST REGION. PROJECT GOAL: THE LUNITA-EAST PROGRAM WILL EXPAND AND ENHANCE SYHEALTH’S EXISTING CARE MANAGEMENT PROGRAMS BY INCREASING ACCESS TO A GREATER NUMBER OF CHILDREN AND FAMILIES. THE OVERARCHING GOAL OF SYHEALTH’S PROPOSED LUNITA-EAST PROGRAM IS TO ENSURE CHILDREN WHO ARE OVERWEIGHT OR OBESE REDUCE THEIR RISK OF DEVELOPING A SERIOUS CHRONIC HEALTH CONDITION THROUGH A) INCREASED ACCESS AND UTILIZATION OF COMPREHENSIVE PEDIATRIC MEDICAL CARE AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES, AND B) INCREASED ENGAGEMENT WITH LOCAL COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS AND SCHOOLS TO IMPROVE ACCESS AND LINKAGE TO SUPPORT SERVICES FOR CHILDREN AND FAMILIES RESIDING IN THE HEALTH CENTER’S SERVICE COMMUNITY. PROJECT METHODOLOGY: THE PROPOSED LUNITA-EAST PROGRAM WILL BUILD UPON SYHEALTH’S PEDIATRIC CARE COORDINATION, HEALTH EDUCATION, AND CLINICAL SERVICES INFRASTRUCTURE. LUNITA-EAST IS DESIGNED TO REACH THE MULTIPLE AND DISTINCT COMMUNITIES (E.G., IRAQI, AFGHAN, IRANIAN, VIETNAMESE) THROUGHOUT SAN DIEGO COUNTY’S EAST REGION. TH E COORDINATED PEDIATRIC CARE MODEL WILL BE TAILORED TO ADDRESS CARE GAPS (I.E., PEDIATRIC HEALTH EDUCATION AND CARE COORDINATION MANAGEMENT) AND PATIENT RELATED SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH (SDOH), VIA PATIENT ENGAGEMENT WITH A DEDICATED CARE TEAM (I.E., CARE COORDINATOR AND HEALTH EDUCATOR). THE ENHANCED PROGRAM DESIGN WILL IMPROVE LINKAGES BETWEEN PRIMARY CARE, HEALTH EDUCATION, CARE COORDINATION, AND SUPPORT SERVICES WITHIN SYHEALTH, AS WELL AS IMPROVE CROSS-REFERRAL PATHWAYS AND LINKAGES TO EXTERNAL RESOURCES AND PROGRAMS FOR CHILDREN/FAMILIES IN THE COMMUNITY. COLLABORATIVE SUPPORT: SYHEALTH’S PROPOSED LUNITA-EAST PROGRAM INCLUDES COMMUNITY COLLABORATION SPECIFICALLY WITH THE AMERICAN ACADEMY OF PEDIATRICS – CALIFORNIA CHAPTER THREE (AAP-CA3), SAN DIEGO HUNGER COALITION AND MOUNTAIN EMPIRE UNIFIED SCHOOL DISTRICT.

HEALTHY TOMORROWS PARTNERSHIP FOR CHILDREN PROGRAM - PROBLEM ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES (ACES) ARE POTENTIALLY TRAUMATIC EVENTS THAT CAUSE OVERWHELMING STRESS AND HAVE LASTING NEGATIVE EFFECTS ON PHYSICAL AND MENTAL HEALTH. SUCH EXPERIENCES INCLUDE ABUSE AND MALTREATMENT (PHYSICAL, SEXUAL, EMOTIONAL/VERBAL); NEGLECT (PHYSICAL AND EMOTIONAL/PSYCHOLOGICAL); AND HOUSEHOLD DYSFUNCTION (PARENT MENTAL ILLNESS; DOMESTIC VIOLENCE; DIVORCE OR SEPARATION; INCARCERATION; AND ALCOHOL OR DRUG ABUSE). TRAUMATIC EVENTS IN CHILDHOOD CAN BE EMOTIONALLY PAINFUL OR DISTRESSING AND CAN HAVE EFFECTS THAT PERSIST FOR YEARS. FACTORS SUCH AS THE NATURE, FREQUENCY AND SERIOUSNESS OF THE TRAUMATIC EVENT, PRIOR HISTORY OF TRAUMA, AND AVAILABLE FAMILY AND COMMUNITY SUPPORTS CAN SHAPE A CHILD’S RESPONSE TO TRAUMA  FOR ALTAMED PEDIATRIC PATIENTS ASSESSED FOR ACES, ONE OF THE MOST CRITICAL SERVICE GAPS IS A LACK OF TIMELY ACCESS TO MENTAL HEALTH/BEHAVIORAL SERVICES. LONG WAIT TIMES TO SEE A MENTAL/BEHAVIORAL HEALTH PROFESSIONAL HAVE BELEAGUERED LOS ANGELES COUNTY, CALIFORNIA AND THE NATION. ALTAMED PEDIATRIC PATIENT/FAMILIES IN NEED OF MENTAL HEALTH/BEHAVIORAL SERVICES BEYOND CASE MANAGEMENT OFTEN WAIT TWO TO THREE MONTH FOR AN APPOINTMENT.  GOALS AND OBJECTIVES GOAL 1: ADVANCE ALTAMED’S ACES CONTINUUM OF CARE THROUGH A CARE COLLABORATION MODEL OF ACES SYSTEMATIC CASE REVIEW.  OBJECTIVE 1. FOUR TO SIX CASES OF CHILDREN AGED 6 MONTHS TO 18 YEARS SCREENED THROUGH PEARLS AND MEETING THE CRITERIA OF COMPLEX ACUITY FOR ACES WILL BE REVIEWED THROUGH A MONTHLY INTERDISCIPLINARY ACES SYSTEMIC CASE REVIEW IN YEARS 1 THROUGH 5.  GOAL 2: ENHANCE TRAUMA INFORMED WRAP AROUND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES FOR CHILDREN/FAMILIES WITH COMPLEX ACUITY FOR ACES.  OBJECTIVE 1. THE PSYCHOLOGY POST-DOCTORAL FELLOW WILL PROVIDE ASSESSMENTS, BRIDGE COUNSELING, AND THERAPEUTIC TREATMENT TO APPROXIMATELY190 UNDER RESOURCED CHILDREN AGED SIX MONTHS TO18 YEARS AND/OR THEIR PARENTS/CAREGIVERS WITH IDENTIFIED COMPLEX CO-OCCURRING PRIMARY CARE AND MENTAL/BEHA VIORAL HEALTH ISSUES IDENTIFIED THROUGH THE ACE SCREENING TOOL (PEARLS) ANNUALLY IN YEARS 1 THROUGH 5.  METHODOLOGY THE PROPOSED ACES-BEHAVIORAL HEALTH COLLABORATION (ACES-BHC) PROJECT WILL BE THE INITIAL CATALYST TO SUPPORT THE INTEGRATION OF PEDIATRIC PRIMARY CARE AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES. ALTAMED HAS CHAMPIONED ACES SCREENING AND IS INVESTED IN IMPLEMENTING EVIDENCED BASED APPROACHES TO ADDRESS ACES AND TOXIC STRESS IN ITS PEDIATRIC PATIENT POPULATION. THE ACES-BHC PROJECT IS A NEW COMPONENT WITHIN ALTAMED’S ACES EMERGING CONTINUUM OF CARE, ENHANCING BEHAVIORAL HEALTH CARE ACCESS AND UTILIZATION TO PEDIATRIC PATIENTS WITH COMPLEX ACUITY FOR ACES THROUGH THE ACES-BHC, ALTAMED WILL 1) ESTABLISH AN INTERDISCIPLINARY SYSTEMATIC CASE REVIEW PROCESS TO FACILITATE RESOURCES FOR PEDIATRIC PATIENTS AND THEIR FAMILIES WITH COMPLEX PHYSICAL AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH ACES CO-MORBIDITY, AS WELL AS PROMOTE WORKFORCE DEVELOPMENT IN PEDIATRIC BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES THROUGH CASE COLLABORATION, COACHING, AND MENTORSHIP; AND  2) HOST A PSYCHOLOGY POST-DOCTORAL FELLOW FROM THE CHILDREN’S HOSPITAL LOS ANGELES USC/UCEDD GRADUATE PSYCHOLOGY EDUCATION PROGRAM TO PROVIDE BRIDGE COUNSELING AND SHORT TERM PSYCHOLOGICAL COUNSELING TO HIGH RISK UNDER RESOURCED CHILDREN AND YOUTH, AND THEIR FAMILIES.   EVALUATION DATA COLLECTION AND TRACKING TOOLS WILL INCLUDE, EPIC ALTAMED’S EMR TO CAPTURE HEALTH-RELATED SERVICES, PROVIDER REFERRALS AND CASE MANAGEMENT NOTES, AS WELL AS EXCEL LOGS TO TRACK PATIENT PARTICIPATION/RESULTS (I.E. PARTICIPATION IN EDUCATIONAL CLASSES, PATIENT SURVEY RESULTS); AND ITS MANAGEMENT INFORMATION SYSTEMS (MIS).   PROCESS EVALUATION WILL BE COMPLETED BY ANALYSIS OF EPIC REPORTS AND EXCEL REPORTS.  OUTCOME EVALUATION WILL CENTER ON PATIENT/PARENT/CAREGIVER SURVEYS CAPTURING PATIENT SATISFACTION AS WELL AS KNOWLEDGE AND BEHAVIOR CHANGE.
